user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_quoted_bin_n:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_quoted_bin_n (const char *quoted,
                            size_t quoted_len,
                            const char *unquoted,
                            size_t unquoted_len)
{
  size_t i;
  size_t j;
  if (unquoted_len < quoted_len / 2)
    return false;

  j = 0;
  for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
  {
    if ('\\' == quoted[i])
    {
      i++; /* Advance to the next character */
      if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
    }
    if (quoted[i] != unquoted[j])
      return false; /* Different characters */
  }
  if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */

  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment is reachable — e.g. quoted = "a", quoted_len = 1, unquoted = "", unquoted_len = 0. The initial check (unquoted_len < quoted_len/2) is false (0 < 0 is false), the for loop body is not entered (unquoted_len > j is false), leaving i == 0 and j == 0. The subsequent if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j)) evaluates (1 != 0) true and returns false. Thus the code fragment can be executed and is not unreachable.
